STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 10, 2024
Timothy Nelson
KENT COUNTY JUVENILE DETENTION CENTER
1501 CEDAR ST,
GRAND RAPIDS, MI, 49503-1300
Re: License #: CO410201223
SI #: 2024SIC0001458
Dear Timothy Nelson:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Repeat violations.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
Phone: (269) 251-2471
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024SIC0001458
Special Investigation Intake Date: May 24, 2024
License #: CO410201223
Licensee Group Organization: 17th Circuit Court Family Division
Licensee Designee: Timothy Nelson
Chief Administrator: Timothy Nelson
Agency Name: KENT COUNTY JUVENILE DETENTION
CENTER
Agency Address: 1501 CEDAR ST
GRAND RAPIDS, MI 49503-1300
License Status: Inspected
License Expiration Date: 09/30/2025
Capacity: 98
II. METHODOLOGY

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Resident restraint
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10177.1
Section (1) The facility shall establish and follow written policy and
Description procedures specifying the use of resident restraint.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 body slammed Youth A up in the air on the concrete inside
of Unit SHU. Youth A was screaming and complaining of shoulder
and arm pain. Youth A was not taken for medical attention nor
was Youth A medically evaluated at the Juvenile Detention
Center. Youth A’s whole body was shaking all day on 05/22/2024.
Investigation Several attempts were made to contact and interview
Complainant but after leaving voice messages, Complainant
never responded.
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were interviewed face-to-
face at the facility on 5/28/2024. Both reported the allegations
are “misinformation” and it appears the complainant doesn’t really
know what is occurring with Youth A. They also reported the
facility has medical records indicating Youth A does not have a
seizure disorder and this has been confirmed through medical
assessments at the hospital. The facility is taking the appropriate
steps to provide for the care of Youth A especially with the serious
problems Youth A presents. Youth A is presenting with a very high
suicidal ideation and engages in self-harming behaviors quite
often. Youth A tried to jump off Youth A’s bed in an attempt to
“smash” Youth A’s head against the wall or mirror. Both report
Youth A has been “relentless” in efforts for self-harm. The incident
outlined in the allegations began in the school when Youth A took
a laptop computer and smashed it against a white board and
stomped on it while the computer was on the floor. After receiving
a consequence for this behavior, Youth A was placed in Youth A’s
room. Once in Youth A’s room, Youth A stood on the bed and did
a “freefall” to the floor. This resulted in Youth A being taken to the
hospital where Youth A was assessed for mental illness issues
and sent back to the facility 3 hours later. They also reported
Youth A was very calm at the hospital and Youth A is reported to
have told a supervisor (unidentified) that Youth A will continue with
self-harming behaviors if returned to the facility. Youth A has been
on one-to-one supervision since the return from the hospital.
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 reported meeting with the
2

Psychiatrist, nursing staff, and therapists of Network 180 to
develop a plan to keep Youth A safe from himself. They have
placed mattresses on the floor so if he jumps off the bed again,
there is less chance of injury. Youth A is wearing a suicide vest.
All of these precautions have been recommended by Network 180
staff. They reported Youth A is allowed out of the bedroom and
into the program (school and other activities) as long as Youth A
promises to not engage in self-harming behaviors. If Youth A
engages in self-harming behaviors, Youth A is returned to his
bedroom. Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were
interviewed again face-to-face at the facility on 5/30/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. They provided a copy of the
video recording and reported watching the video recording.
Neither had any concerns with the restraint and reported
Supervisor was present during the whole incident. Staff 1 took
control of the situation and had to readjust the hold which caused
them to flip over and place Youth A on the floor. Both reported
Staff 1 is “one of the best and does things by the book”. They will
use Staff 1 to help train other staff because he is “just that good at
it”. They reported Youth A is allowed normal activities during the
day if he is not threatening self-harm but at night Youth A will
sleep in the observation room.
Youth A was observed face-to-face at the facility on
5/28/2024. Youth A did not respond to “hi” and was laying on 2
mattresses on the floor of Youth A’s room. Staff (unidentified) was
sitting in the doorway of the room. Youth A was attempted to be
interviewed again face-to-face at the facility on 5/30/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A refused to be
interviewed when asked.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/28/2024. He reported responding to a call for assistance on the
SHU unit where Youth A was lodged. Upon arriving to the unit,
Staff 1 observed Youth A in the bedroom (observation room) with
the door closed. Staff 1 had been told (did not identify source) that
Youth A had placed items in front of the camera and was
obstructing the view. Staff 1 reported opening the door to the room
and attempting to deescalate Youth A. Staff 1 informed Youth A
that the bedding will be removed (self-harm process) and Youth A
told Staff 1 that Staff 1 can’t take the bedding. Youth A grabbed
the sheets and mattress. Staff 1 reported the other staff (unsure
who this individual was) in the room grabbed the mattress and
Staff 1 began the standing hold of Youth A because Youth A was
hiding items on Youth A’s person. Staff 1 attempted to place
Youth A in a neutral floor position but because Youth A was close
3

to the bed and toilet they had to back up before Staff 1 placed
Youth A in a neutral position on the ground. Staff 1 reported
having to modify his hold and take down of Youth A because of
the obstacles including the toilet and bed. Staff 1 reported being
between Youth A and the ground when they went to the ground
during the restraint. The items were removed from Youth A and
after Staff 1 released the hold and stood up, Youth A said “I still
have stuff”. Staff 1 reported Youth A had no injuries and never
complained or said Youth A was hurt. Staff 1 reported having a
good relationship with Youth A and has been involved in several
incidents to help deescalate Youth A and get Youth A back into
the program appropriately. Staff 1 reported hearing (unable to
identify from whom) that Staff 1 body slammed Youth A to the
floor but denied doing such behavior. Staff 1 identified Supervisor
and Staff 4 present at the time of the restraint.
Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
being present during the restraint outlined in the allegations and
identified Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 4, Staff 6, Staff 7, Staff 8, and
Administrator 3 being present. He reported Staff 3 and Staff 5
were monitoring the situation from the control room using video
feeds. He reported the restraint took place at approximately
10am, after Youth A earned a consequence while in school. When
Youth A got to his bedroom, Youth A began to threaten diving off
the bed before sticking toilet paper over the camera. Youth A then
put toilet paper into his pants and tied his shirt around the neck at
which time staff (unknown) informed Network 180 of Youth A’s
actions. Supervisor was trying to deescalate Youth A, but Youth A
refused to give up his clothing which was recommended by
Network 180. Supervisor reported Youth A engaged in “seizure”
activity by laying on the ground and holding Youth A’s breath and
shaking. At this time, medical staff showed up and gave Youth A
oxygen. Supervisor reported being informed by Administrator 1 to
place Youth A in a supine neutral position when restraining to
keep Youth A from harming self. Throughout this time, staff
continued to try and deescalate Youth A through verbal prompts.
Youth A was restrained twice during this time with the first
restraint being conducted by Staff 1 and the second restraint
being conducted by Staff 4. Supervisor reported Staff 1 had to
modify the technique used because of the small space and not
wanting Youth A to hit the toilet or bed. Staff 1 was able to place
Youth A in a supine neutral position once adjusting for the space.
Supervisor reported not having any issues with the modification
Staff 1 used to ensure Youth A was safe. The purpose of the first
resistant to was obtain the items Youth A had in his possession.
4

Supervisor reported the second restraint was initiated to remove
Youth A’s clothing and this involved Staff 4. Staff 4 used
appropriate techniques to remove Youth A’s clothing and place
Youth A in a protective suicide vest. Supervisor reported
mechanical restraint items were used to transport Youth A to the
hospital on a gurney. He reported Youth A never said anything
about any injury or that Youth A was hurt. Administrator 3 checked
Youth A prior to the transport to the hospital.
Administrator 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
being present during the restraints outlined in the allegations. She
reported that if staff did not hold Youth A in a neutral position,
Youth A would get on the bed and jump off hitting Youth A’s head
causing Youth A to harm self. She reported no concerns with the
restraints and believed staff were being very gentle with Youth A.
She reported Staff 1 was very calm during the restraints and has a
great reputation working with youth at the facility. Youth A never
complained of any injury or pain during or following the 2
restraints. Once Youth A presented with seizure activity,
Administrator 3 called the doctor to get orders for Youth A to be
admitted to the hospital and Youth A went to the hospital in an
ambulance. She reported Youth A has been assessed and does
not present with the brain patterns to support a seizure. She
believed Youth A will hold his breath until passing out claiming it is
a seizure. Network 180 and the facility administration has
developed a special program for Youth A which involves getting
Youth A into the program activities as long as Youth A is not
threatening or attempting self-harming behaviors. This also
involves having staff with good relationships with Youth A working
with Youth A as much as possible. Youth A is allowed to go to
Youth A’s room if feeling frustrated so Youth A can relax and calm
down before behaving in a way that will result in a consequence.
Administrator 3 reported mattresses are to be placed on the floor
to keep Youth A from hitting Youth A’s head against the floor
when diving off the bed and Youth A is on one-to-one supervision.
Administrator 3 reported Youth A has stated that Youth A will
continue with the self-harming attempts until death and then Youth
A will watch the facility on the news from Heaven.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
being present but not involved in the restraint. He reported Staff 1
didn’t use the normal (taught) restraint technique when taking
Youth A to the floor at the beginning of the restraint. He was
unable to identify why Staff 1 would “modify” the technique and
5

believed this caused Youth A to move more towards the back wall
of the room. He reported never hearing Youth A say anything
about being hurt during or after the restraint. He reported the
restraint was initiated after it was identified (on the radio to staff
and unknown from who) as a safety risk because Youth A was
using toilet paper to cover the camera view and Youth A had a
history of self-harming behaviors. Staff 2’s biggest concerns were
the use of mechanical restraint items when restraining Youth A.
He reported this began after Youth A was return from the hospital
and increased supervision techniques were introduced. He
reported being verbally informed by administration that the use of
mechanical restraint technology would be used and would have
preferred this information was presented in a written policy change
with “clear guidelines”.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 3 reported
working in central control and observing the restraint on camera.
After observing Youth A being escorted back to the observation
room and putting wet toilet paper over the camera lens to obstruct
viewing, Staff 3 called for floating staff to go to the observation
room for support. After observing Staff 1 engage in the restraint
when Youth A refused to give up the toilet paper Youth A had in
Youth A’s pants, Staff 3 reported the technique used by Staff 1
didn’t appear to be a “handle with care” technique. He reported
Staff 1 had his arms over the top of Youth A’s arms which is not a
trained technique. Staff 3 believed the initiation of the restraint by
Staff 1 was not done according to the Handle with Care training
because Staff 1 used a “bear hug” before grabbing Youth A’s
arms. Staff 3 reported observing other restraints by Staff 1 and
Staff 1 has always used appropriate techniques. Staff 3’s other
concern was the use of mechanical restraints because staff have
not been provided policy in writing on this change and several
staff (unidentified) are uncomfortable.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
being present when the restraint occurred. He reported working as
a floating staff and received a radio call that staff need support for
Youth A in the observation room. When getting to the room, Staff
4 observed Youth A making self-harming treats “I can fall
backwards and bust my head on the window”, and stated other
scenarios of what Youth A could do to self-harm. He reported staff
were waiting for the Network 180 staff to show up because the
Network 180 staff wanted Youth A placed in a suicide suit to help
avoid self-harming behaviors. Staff 4 reported Youth A took toilet
6

paper and covered the camera lens while also stuffing toilet paper
in Youth A’s pants and under the mattress. Staff 1 initiated the
restraint and Staff 4 attempted to tell Staff 1 that Staff 4 was able
to do the restraint, but Staff 1 still engaged. Staff 4 reported not
wanting to argue in front of Youth A, so he didn’t confront Staff 1
at the time. Staff 4 reported Supervisor was present at the time to
observe staff’s interactions with Youth A. Staff 4 reported Staff 1
grabbed Youth A’s right arm with Staff 1’s two arms but normally
the technique is to put an arm under the youth’s arm and turn
while putting staff’s other arm under the youth’s other arm. Staff 4
doesn’t believe this was a taught technique to initiate a restraint.
Staff 4 denied hearing Youth A complain of any pain and reported
Youth A was laughing during the restraint. Staff 4 reported not
telling anyone of his concerns of the restraint because he doesn’t
believe Staff 1 did anything with malignant intentions and the
physical condition of the room (space between bed and toilet) did
not allow Staff 1 to get behind Youth A as trained. Staff 4’s other
concern is the lack of a written policy on the use of mechanical
restraints because staff are fearful of getting in trouble if using this
technology.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
working in central control and observing the restraint of Youth A
by Staff 1. He reported the restraint of Youth A by Staff 1, “didn’t
look clean”. Staff 5 reported the initiation of the restraint looked
like more of a “bear hug” rather than Staff 5 grabbing Youth A’s
arms as taught with the Handle with Care. He reported having no
concerns about Staff 1’s restraints in the past. Staff 5 reported a
concern of the use of mechanical restraints because there is no
written policy and staff are fearful of getting into trouble. He
reported feeling “burnt out” over the stress of trying to keep Youth
A safe when Youth A keeps trying to self-harm.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 6 reported
arriving on the scene when Staff 1 was trying to place Youth A in a
standing hold and observed Staff 1 turn Youth A and place Youth
A in a neutral position on the floor. Staff 6 believed the techniques
used by Staff 1 were appropriate because “you just have to do the
best you can”. Staff 6 reported not hearing Youth A complain of
any pain or injury.
Staff 7 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 7
reported being present during the restraint of Youth A by Staff 1.
7

He was working a different unit when receiving a call for support to
Youth A’s observation room. When getting to the location, Staff 1
had Youth A in the restraint and placed Youth A on the floor. Staff
7 reported the restraint was different because of the situation with
the toilet and bed taking up space. Staff 1 lifted Youth A up off the
ground as Youth A’s feet came off the ground and Staff 1 placed
Youth A on the ground. Because Staff 7 had been on the job for
only a short time, he didn’t question the restraint techniques used
until completing his training 2-days later. After completing the
restraint training, Staff 7 now believed the techniques used by
Staff 1 were not appropriate. Staff 7 reported the hip thrust when
picking up Youth A was inappropriate but understands this took
place so Youth A would not hit Youth A’s legs on the toilet nor hit
Youth A’s head on the wall.
Staff 8 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
not being present during the restraints but was present prior and
aware the safety issues that were put into place because of Youth
A’s threats to self-harm. When she was in the observation room of
Youth A, Youth A was standing against the wall smiling and
stating that Youth A was happy because Youth A was going to kill
himself and get the facility into trouble for Youth A’s death. After
Youth A made a gesture of jumping off the bed, Staff 8 informed
Supervisor that Youth A needs to be placed in the suicide vest.
Staff 8 left the room prior to the restraints. She reported Youth A
has been diagnosed with Bipolar 1 with psychotic features and
major depressive disorder. She reported Youth A is allowed into
the normal program if Youth A promises to show positive
cooperative behaviors and follows through with this change. Youth
A is only placed in high-risk protocol when showing self-harming
behaviors and then only as long as these behaviors persist.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/30/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B
reported living on the same unit (SHU) as Youth A and was
present with the situation began in the classroom with Youth A.
Youth B described Youth A as talking about inappropriate things
and not following directions from staff. Youth B reported never
observing staff being inappropriate with Youth A. Youth B reported
the program is helping and Youth B feels safe at the facility.
Video Review
The video is dated 5/21/2024 and there is no time stamp. The
view is from above the door leading into the observation room
towards the back wall where the toilet is located. Within this view,
8

the bed is observed against the right back wall. Youth A is
standing close to the back wall, between the toilet and bed with
Youth A’s hands clinched and held down at Youth A’s sides.
Youth A has toilet paper in Youth A’s left hand. Supervisor and
Staff 1 are standing to the right side and in front of Youth A as the
video begins. Both Supervisor and Staff 1 back away from Youth
A to the doorway. Supervisor and Staff 1 walk back into the room
and Staff 1 moves to Youth A and grabs Youth A by the shoulders
with Youth A backing up to the back wall. Staff 6 enters the room
following Supervisor and Staff 1. Staff 4 quickly enters the room,
moving past Staff 2 and stands right behind Staff 1 who is
engaged in the standing hold of Youth A who is against the back
wall. Staff 4 attempts to grab items out of Youth A’s left hand but
Youth A pulls his left arm away from Staff 4. Staff 2 has moved
into the room behind Supervisor, Staff 1, and Staff 4. Staff 1 is still
holding Youth A from the front, when he, Youth A, and Staff 4
begin to walk towards the middle of the room before Staff 1 begins
to move towards the floor, taking Youth A with him. Staff 4
appears to get the item from Youth A’s left hand. Staff 4 backs
away and Staff 1 holds Youth A by the shoulder and turns to his
left flipping Youth A while Youth A’s feet leave the ground and
placing Youth A on the floor between the toilet and bed with Staff
1 above Youth A. Youth A appears to be on Youth A’s left side
with Staff 1 straddled above Youth A in a kneeling position.
Supervisor moved to the left of Staff 1 and Staff 6 moves to the
right of Staff 1. Staff 4 has left the room. Staff 6 moved to a
kneeling position and holds Youth A’s legs. Staff 2 enters the
room and stands behind Staff 1 and Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
Medical Patient Note for Youth A dated 5/21/24 and authored
by Staff 9. This document outlines medical staff’s (Staff 9)
assessment of Youth A on 5/21/24. Youth A was assessed for
“seizure” behaviors in Youth A’s room. Youth A’s breathing was
within normal range for the movements of Youth A’s body. Youth
A presented with O2 saturation of 99% and was attempting to hold
Youth A’s breath before beginning to breath normally again. Youth
A did not present with any symptoms of a seizure and Youth A’s
behaviors of a seizure appear to be behavioral rather than
medical.
Off-site Emergency Referral ER-9.0 dated 5/21/24. This
document outlines the emergency services provided for Youth A.
It is documented the ambulance was provided for transportation of
Youth A to the Trinity Health emergency room. The reason for this
referral is staff’s observation of Youth A on the SHU unit. Youth A
9

was presenting with self-convulsing body only and limbs were not
noted to be shaking, respirations were in normal range for Youth
A’s body movements, and Youth A had a O2 saturation of 99%.
Youth A attempted to hyperventilate but then slowed breathing to
normal breathing pattern. Youth A’s eyes reacted to his eyes
being opened. It is documented that this is observed as behavioral
rather than medical.
Incident 179109 for Youth A dated 5/21/24 authored by Staff 8.
This document outlines the observation of Youth A by Staff 8
when she entered the observation room after Youth A had
become dysregulated. This matches the report provided in the
interview of Staff 8.
Incident 179110 for Youth A dated 5/21/24 authored by
several staff.
• Primary authored by Staff 10. This narrative outlines the
incident in the classroom that led to Youth A going to the
observation room for violation and aggressive behaviors.
This begins and ends in the classroom where Youth A is
documented as throwing the laptop at a large screen
television.
• Supplemental authored by Staff 1. This narrative is
consistent with what was reported by Staff 1 during his
interview. Staff 1 described the restraint as a Primary
Restraint Technique (PRT) in response to Youth A refusing
the directions given by Supervisor over removing all items
from the room.
• Supplemental authored by Staff 2. This narrative is
consistent with what was reported by Staff 2 during his
interview. Staff 2 described the restraint as Staff 1 placing
Youth A in a PRT before placing Youth A in a “neutral
position”.
• Supplemental authored by Staff 6. This narrative is
consistent with what was reported by Staff 6 during his
interview. Staff 6 documents Staff 1 placing Youth A on the
floor in a neutral position as a result of Youth A refusing to
comply with the directions provided by Supervisor.
• Supplemental authored by Supervisor. This narrative
documents that Youth A was placed in a safety vest due to
threats and attempts at self-harm.
• Second Supplemental authored by Supervisor. This
narrative outlines the actions taken by Youth A prior to the
restraint with Staff 1. It is documented that Supervisor
10

asked several times that Youth A provide the paper hidden
on Youth A’s person before Supervisor authorized the
restraint in an effort to retrieve the paper which was
retrieved during the restraint by Staff 1. The type of
restraint or further description was not identified in this
narrative. Further narrative outlines the second restraint to
remove Youth A’s clothing and placed in a safety vest.
Finally, it is documented the process of Youth A’s order for
an assessment at the emergency room.
• Supplemental authored by Staff 7. This narrative is
consistent with was reported by Staff 7 during his interview.
Staff 7 described the restraint as Youth A being placed in a
PRT (unknown who the staff were) and Staff 1 and Staff 4
having Youth A in a neutral position.
Detention Procedures Manual – Resident Management 600.16
dated 8/24/2016. This document outlines the use of
physical/mechanical restraint by staff with youth in the facility.
Staff are to use the approved Handle with Care behavior
management system when applying behavior management and all
staff are to be trained on the appropriate techniques of this
process.
Handle with Care Behavior Management System physical
intervention manual for participants dated 2012. This manual
outlines the different strategies when engaging in a physical
intervention. It is documented that the “Solo Takedown” which
Staff 1 engaged in should occur with the staff standing behind the
youth locking the staff’s arms under the youth’s arms with the
staff’s hands placed on the upper back of the youth. Staff are to
be standing behind the youth before beginning the “takedown”.
The next action by staff is described as taking a long step back
lowering staff’s center of gravity, drawing the youth off balance.
Staff’s palms are against the youth’s back to support the youth’s
weight. Staff are then to lower their knee to the floor, slowly
staging the youth’s descent to a sitting position before staff drops
their other knee to the floor. This final action by staff will bring the
youth to a sitting position on the floor. Staff are then to “pivot their
knee” and gently turn the youth 180 degrees to the neutral
position.
Staff 1’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 1 was
hired in 8/8/2016 and there is no disciplinary action documents in
the file. Documentation in the file indicates Staff 1 completed
behavior management refresher (HWC 4 hours) on 10/17/23. Staff
1 is current on all training requirements.
11

Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per video review,
Staff1 did not utilize an approved restraint technique when he bear
hugged Youth A, lifting Youth A off the ground and then bringing
Youth A to the ground. Several staff interviewed reported the
technique used by Staff 1 was not appropriate and Staff 1
admitted during the interview that he “modified” the technique.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered in regard to providing written
policies and procedures to staff using the approved mechanical
restraint equipment when needed with Youth A. Staff presented as
fearful of incurring consequences when using the mechanical
restraint equipment with Youth A and also fearful of Youth A
following through with the treats to self-harm.
Technical assistance was also offered in regard to staff’s fear of
providing enough care to keep Youth A from self-harming as
threatened by Youth A. It was recommended that the
administration provide training in dealing with mental health issues
that Youth A presents and allowing staff to have a voice to share
their concerns.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2023C0000413 dated 4/19/23, CAP approved 6/12/23
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
7/9/2024
______________________________________
Paul Fatato Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 10, 2024
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
13
